results.title: Joan Kirner
results.creator_credit: ACMI, Lisetta Moscardo and Helen Simondson
results.brief_description: Best known for her appointment as Australia’s first female Premier in Victoria in 1990, Joan Kirner has a long history of working towards gender equality and social justice spanning five decades. In this intimate bio-doc, Kirner shares stories of the challenges and motivators of leadership in community and political spheres. Kirner has been has been pivotal in the areas of education reform, the formation of the first Landcare groups, affirmative action for women in government and was co-founder of EMILY’s List.
results.description: Best known for her appointment as Australia’s first female Premier in Victoria in 1990, Joan Kirner has a long history of working towards gender equality and social justice spanning five decades. Kirner has been has been pivotal in the areas of education reform, the formation of the first Landcare groups, affirmative action for women in government and was co-founder of EMILY’s List.

results.title: Fire threat
results.brief_description: A young mum recounts her stress at her partner deciding to stay in Warburton while she and her young daughter go to her mum’s house. She speaks about her ‘uni days’ and the change in priorities now that she is a mum.

results.title: In a knot
results.brief_description: ‘Warburton, which is practically my life.’ A sparse story, fairly poetic, about her stress and anxiety and fighting with her family. Amazing photos - from a light plane looking over the ‘Black Saturday’ affected areas.

results.title: Freedom rides
results.creator_credit: Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Blood brothers”.
Charles Perkins grew up in Alice Springs in a time when racial segregation was the rule. Sent away to Adelaide for an education he became increasingly aware of the injustices perpetrated against Australian First Nations peoples. In 1965 he instigated the “Freedom ride” - a busload of concerned people, mostly students - who visited outback Australia, notably Walgett and Moree, to escalate the level of public awareness of racial intolerance in Australia. This video documents that journey and talks to those who took part.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Rachel Perkins, Ned Lander and City Pictures
